questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a mass per vagina. It has been getting progressively more prominent. She has started to notice that she leaks urine while laughing and sneezing. She is sexually active and her husband had a vasectomy. You diagnose a second-degree cystocele. She has no uterine prolapse or rectocele. Which of the following is the best treatment plan to offer this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical correction with a bladder neck suspension procedure

questions.correct_answer: D. Surgical correction with a bladder neck suspension procedure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgical correction with a bladder neck suspension procedure Surgical therapy for stress urinary incontinence attributed to cystocele and loss of urethral support involves the suspension of the bladder neck via Kelly plication, retropubic suspension (Marshall-Marcheƫ-Krantz and Burch procedures), or sling procedures (Pereyra and Stamey procedures or transobturator or transvaginal tapes).

Highyeild:

Stress urinary incontinence is the most common incontinence in young women. It is the result of rises in bladder pressure due to intra-abdominal pressure increases. Gold standard surgery: Colposuspension Treatment of choice: Trans Obturator Tape/Trans Vaginal Tape.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Anticholinergic drugs such as Ditropan (oxybutynin chloride ) are used to relax the bladder in the treatment of detrusor instability. Option B : Placement of a pessary is an option to relieve a cystocele, but is not ideal in this patient, who is sexually active. Option C : Le Fort procedure is performed in patients with vaginal vault prolapse and pelvic relaxation who are poor surgical candidates and not sexually active . The procedure involves obliterating the vaginal canal to provide support to the pelvic structures.

Extraedge:

For rectocele posterior colpoperineorrhaphy is done.

questions.text: A 48-year-old G3P3 woman has leakage of urine with coughing and sneezing. She denies dysuria or urinary urgency. Which of the following is likely to be present on physical examination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypermobile urethra This patient has symptoms consistent with pure stress urinary incontinence, typically due to the bladder falling out of its normal intra-abdominal position. When she bears down (Valsalva), the pressure on the bladder causes loss of urine. Another component of urinary incontinence is loss of the vesicourethral angle and hypermobile urethra . The common denominator is probably childbirth, leading to damage of the pelvic support.

Highyeild:

Stress incontinence occurs when the tissue that supports the urethra gets weak. The bladder and urethra are supported by the pelvic floor muscles. Urine flows from the bladder through the urethra to the outside. Gold standard surgery: Colposuspension Treatment of choice: Trans Obturator Tape/Trans Vaginal Tape.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient P5L5 c/o involuntary loss of urine for 3 months. She goes for a morning jog during which she has to wear absorbent pads. Pelvic examination shows normal external genitalia and a vaginal bulge, she loses small amounts of urine when asked to cough. Post-void residual urine volume is 80ml. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urethral hypermobility Diagnosis: Stress urinary incontinence with cystocele.

Highyeild:

It results from pelvic floor weakness associated with obesity, multiparity, and pelvic surgery. Injury to the pelvic floor muscles causes urethral hypermobility and urethral prolapse. Prolapse of the bladder causes vaginal bulge in this patient. With the rise in intra-abdominal pressures, bladder pressure rises and simultaneous loss of urine occurs. Urethral hypermobility includes the Q tip test which determines whether the patient has an abnormal urethrovesical angle. It is done by placing the patient in a dorsal lithotomy position and inserting a cotton swab into the urethral orifice. An angle of greater than or equal to 30 degrees from horizontal on increasing intra-abdominal pressure signifies urethral hypermobility. Urinalysis and post-void residual volume should be normal ( < 150 mL in women and < 50ml in men ). First-line treatment - kegel exercise . Unresponsive cases may require urethral sling surgery. Vaginal pessary in poor surgical candidates.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Detrusor overactivity is, inappropriate bladder contraction/spasm resulting in urgency followed by involuntary loss of urine at any time, not only with increased intra-abdominal pressure. Option C: Vesicovaginal fistula presents with continual leakage of urine. Option D : BOO causes overflow incontinence characterised by loss of urine from an over-distended bladder and a marked increase in PVR volume.

questions.text: The disadvantage of the Marshall Marchetti Krantz procedure compared with other surgical alternatives for the treatment of stress urinary incontinence includes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both B and C

Highyeild:

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK) procedure, involves the attachment of the periurethral tissue to the symphysis pubis. In approximately 3% of patients undergoing the procedure, osteitis pubis develops, and because of its low cure rate, MMK is less preferred.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A is false.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman attends the gynaecology clinic complaining of urinary incontinence, 3 months after suffering a third-degree perineal tear during a normal vaginal delivery. The doctor says that the tear has weakened her levator and muscle. Which muscle forms the main bulk of the levator ani muscle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Puborectalis The pubococcygeus and puborectalis parts of the levator ani help maintain the tone of the rectum as well as create the anorectal angle and the bulk of the levator ani is puborectalis >>> ileorectalis.

Highyeild:

The levator ani muscle arises from condensations of the obturator fascia which forms the tendinous arch of the levator ani. The vaginal, urethral, and rectal lumen are occluded by the contraction of the levator ani. Relaxation of the muscle is needed for defecation and urination.

Extraedge:

The main support of the uterus is the levator ani and the broad ligament is not a support.

Solution:

Stress urinary incontinence Bonney’s test is a test primarily used for demonstration of stress urinary incontinence only.

Highyeild:

Bonney’s test is performed in the clinical evaluation of SUI. In Bonney’s test, two fingers are placed in the vagina at the UV junction on either side of the urethra and the bladder neck is elevated. On straining or coughing, leakage of urine indicates a positive test . A positive test indicates that the SUI is due to bladder neck descent and urethral hypermobility and can be corrected by bladder neck suspension surgeries. A negative test i.e. leakage of urine-means SUI is due to intrinsic urethral sphincteric deficiency and the results of performing bladder neck suspension surgery will not be good.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

The Marchetti test is the same as Bonney’s test, but two Allis forceps are used instead of fingers.

questions.text: A 41-year-old patient presents with a history suggestive of an overactive bladder, but also complains of faecal incontinence. The patient has tried conservative measures and various anticholinergic with no significant benefit. Urodynamic testing confirms detrusor overactivity and some voiding dysfunction. What is the best surgical option for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Botulinum toxin injections to the bladder and teaching the patient intermittent self-catheterisation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sacral neuromodulation Sacral neuromodulation is employed to treat patients with an overactive bladder and who have not responded to medication therapy. It is also successful in treating patients with faecal incontinence and voiding dysfunction . All other treatments ( options A, B and C) may help only with the overactive bladder symptoms. The first line for overactive bladder is medications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a history of increased urinary frequency, nocturia, urgency and occasional urgency incontinence. What would be the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urinalysis In all females with urinary incontinence, infection or urinary tract pathology must be excluded. Urinalysis and urine culture should be sent during the initial visit.

Highyeild:

Stress incontinence occurs when the tissue that supports the urethra gets weak. The bladder and urethra are supported by the pelvic floor muscles. Urine flows from the bladder through the urethra to the outside. Gold standard surgery: Colposuspension Treatment of choice: Trans Obturator Tape/Trans Vaginal Tape.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D. are false

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a history of pelvic pain, urinary urgency, increased frequency and nocturia. The pelvic pain tends to occur during bladder filling and is relieved by voiding and you suspect that the patient has interstitial cystitis. What other mandatory investigation is required in order to make an accurate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystoscopy It is estimated that about 1% of women with interstitial cystitis would eventually be diagnosed as having transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder . Therefore, some advocate that cystoscopy is mandatory.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Questionnaires (e.g. pelvic pain and urgency/frequency scales) can be used for diagnosis but not to rule out any sinister pathology . Option D: A bladder diary would show low volumes and increased frequency but this is not diagnostic. Likewise, urodynamics would show a hypersensitive bladder with low capacity.

Extraedge:

There are 2 types of cystoscopy: Flexible cystoscopy – a thin (about the width of a pencil), the bendy cystoscope is used, and you stay awake while it's carried out. Rigid cystoscopy – a slightly wider cystoscope that does not bend is used, and you're either put to sleep or the lower half of your body is numbed while it's carried out.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient is suffering from symptoms of an overactive bladder. Her BMI is 25 kg/m2 and the patient is interested in lifestyle changes. What is the most important lifestyle change that you would recommend?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Avoidance of caffeinated drinks There are a few randomized controlled trials demonstrating significant improvement in urinary incontinence and quality of life after following weight reduction programs. Based on a few observational studies, exercise, unless associated with weight loss, does not decrease urinary incontinence. Reduction in fluid is only weakly associated with improvement in urinary incontinence and avoidance of caffeinated drinks helps with symptoms of urgency and not stress incontinence. Large cohort studies have shown no improvement with the reduction of alcohol and either stress incontinence or overactive bladder symptoms.

questions.text: A 34-year-old Para 1 patient presents with stress incontinence with no other urinary symptoms. What would be the first line of management?

options.label: A
options.text: A trial of pelvic floor muscle training for at least 3 months

options.label: B
options.text: Electric stimulation in combination with pelvic floor muscle training

questions.correct_answer: A. A trial of pelvic floor muscle training for at least 3 months
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A trial of pelvic floor muscle training for at least 3 months Pelvic floor muscle training should be offered as first-line management and should consist of eight contractions done three times weekly for at least 3 months. Medical and surgical treatment would be an option if pelvic floor muscle training fails and urodynamic stress incontinence is confirmed.

Highyeild:

Stress incontinence occurs when the tissue that supports the urethra gets weak. The bladder and urethra are supported by the pelvic floor muscles. Urine flows from the bladder through the urethra to the outside. Gold standard surgery: Colposuspension Treatment of choice: Trans Obturator Tape/Trans Vaginal Tape.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.
